awd_titl_txt: Origin of highly heterogeneous Strontium Isotopic Ratio in melt inclusions from oceanic hotspot lavas
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding volcanic processes associated with plumes of mantle material, called hotspots, like those that form the Hawaiian and Samoan Islands or Iceland, is critical for understanding both how the Earth works and how we can best manage resources and hazards on these islands. Hotspot-derived island chains are generated by buoyant plumes of hot rock that rise from the lower mantle and partially melt in the upper mantle. A portion of this melt is erupted as lava on Earth's surface. Because these hotspot-derived lavas are melts of plume material, ultimately derived from the deepest portion of the mantle, their isotopic compositions provide critical information about the compositional makeup of the deep Earth, which is otherwise inaccessible. Studies examining the composition of oceanic lavas have traditionally focused on analyses of entire rocks, for which several kilograms have to be powdered and homogenized before any analyses can be done. The powder is then analyzed for its isotopic composition.  Another way to get this information is to use tiny blebs of melt, called melt inclusions, that are trapped in the lavas. These inclusions, however, have been found to exhibit highly heterogeneous isotopic compositions that are significantly different from the bulk lava. The origin of this extreme variability in melt inclusions is not well understood. This research targets individual olivine-hosed melt inclusions from Samoan lavas. These inclusions will be comprehensively analyzed using novel, state-of-the-art isotopic and geochemical analytical techniques and will also be analyzed for strontium and neodymium isotopes. This geochemical information, all collected on the same inclusion, will shed light on both the origin of Samoan lavas as well as help to unravel the complex geochemical signature carried by melt inclusions, thus, enabling better interpretation of the message they carry. Broader impacts of the work include international collaboration with Dutch scientists at the Virje University-Amsterdam, training and mentoring of undergraduates from groups and minorities underrepresented in the sciences, graduate student support and training, and the transfer of new technology and geochemical methodology to a newly established geochemical facility in the USA at the University of California, Santa Barbara. 

Whole rock geochemical analyses of ocean island basalts have long been considered windows into the chemical composition of the mantle. However, blebs of trapped melt in magmatic phenocrysts, called melt inclusions, complicate this picture because melt inclusions from a single lava can exhibit highly heterogeneous 87Sr/86Sr ratios that span much of the variability observed in oceanic lavas globally. Previous work identified extreme 87Sr/86Sr variability in olivine-hosted melt inclusions from lavas collected at the Samoan, Hawaiian, and Icelandic hotspots.  However, the origin of this variability remains a source of debate. Hypotheses range from it being the result of mixing pristine magmas from isotopically diverse mantle sources to the result of crustal assimilation. This research takes melt inclusions from the Island of Samoa and geochemically analyzes their major, trace element, and volatile (S, Cl and F) concentrations. The isotopes of strontium and neodymium of individual melt inclusions will also be analyzed to provide insight into the origin of the melts and their meaning. The new data examines three hypotheses for the origin of 87Sr/86Sr variability in olivine-hosted melt inclusions: variability is the result of (1) the mixing of pristine mantle-derived melts, (2) the assimilation of shallow altered oceanic crust, and (3) the assimilation of deep gabbroic oceanic crust. Implications of the work have significant value to interpretation of melt inclusions and what they can and cannot tell us about their source, magmatic processes, and the mantle.

por.por_cntn:
The origin of geochemical variability in oceanic hotspot lavas is a long-standing question. The goal of this grant is to constrain the poorly-understood origin of geochemical variability in melt inclusions—blebs of melt trapped in magmatic phenocrysts—hosted within a single lava: prior studies have shown that melt inclusions from a single lava can exhibit highly heterogeneous 87Sr/86Sr ratios that span much of the variability observed in oceanic lavas globally, but the origin of the isotopic diversity in melt inclusions remains a source of debate.

In order to address this debate, the work in this grant combined major, trace, and volatile (S, Cl, F) element concentrations, as well as Sr and Nd isotopic compositions, in individual olivine-hosted melt inclusions. We used these data to evaluate a set of hypotheses to test for the origin of isotopic variability in a suite of melt inclusions from oceanic hotspot lavas.

In the first portion of the project, more than 100 glassy melt inclusions from a single scoria cone at Mauna Loa were analyzed for major, trace, and volatile element (Cl, F, S) concentrations and host olivine major and minor elemental concentrations. The elemental abundances and ratios were then used to prospect for a subset of inclusions that sampled the full range of geochemical compositions, and approximately 30 of these melt inclusions were targeted for 87Sr/86Sr characterization. In order to carry out the Sr isotope measurements, we developed a low-blank (down to 3 picograms), low-analyte (down to 200 picograms) method for analysis of Sr isotopes in individual olivine-hosted melt inclusions by Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometry. There are two primary findings from this study. First, in contrast to Sobolev et al. (Nature, 2011)—who identified extreme Sr-isotopic heterogeneity in melt inclusions from the same Mauna Loa scoria cone locality—we find essentially no Sr-isotopic variability (see Anderson et al., G-cubed, 2021). Second, a Mauna Loa melt inclusion with the highest Sr/Ce ratio ever identified in Hawaii was also targeted for Sr-isotopic analyses. We found that the Mauna Loa melt inclusion with highest Sr/Ce has identical 87Sr/86Sr to other Mauna Loa lavas with normal Sr/Ce ratios, an observation that does not support an earlier hypothesis (Sobolev et al., Nature, 2001) that argues high Sr/Ce melt inclusions sample ancient recycled gabbro. This is because the Sobolev et al. (Nature, 2001) hypothesis would predict that variable inputs of ancient recycled gabbro—responsible for the variable Sr/Ce in Mauna Loa inclusions—would yield variable 87Sr/86Sr in the melt inclusions (unless the proposed ancient recycled gabbro evolved, by chance, to have the exact same 87Sr/86Sr as other Mauna Loa mantle components lacking a recycled gabbro signature, a possibility that is unlikely). We argue that a simpler explanation is that the high Sr/Ce and homogeneous 87Sr/86Sr in Mauna Loa melt inclusions results from shallow-level diffusive interaction between percolating Mauna Loa melts and plagioclase-rich Mauna Loa cumulates, which impart high Sr/Ce on the percolating melts.

Having developed a low-blank, low-analyte method for 87Sr/86Sr analysis in silicates, the second portion of the project employed the new analytical capabilities to target single mineral grains (olivine, orthopyroxene, and clinopyroxene) in peridotite mantle xenoliths for 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd analyses. To accomplish this task, we also developed a method for micro-analysis of 143Nd/144Nd in samples hosting as little as 100 picograms of Nd, with total procedural blanks as low as 220 femtograms. We find that a single small (4 x 2 cm) carbonatite metasomatized peridotite mantle xenolith from Samoa can exhibit extreme 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd variability at the scale of individual mineral grains—representing up to ~20% of the total variability in the oceanic mantle—and we argue this is due to multiple pulses of small volumes of highly enriched carbonatite melts (Byerly et al., G-cubed, 2021).

The implications of the proposed work reach beyond ocean island basalt geochemistry. Our new methods for analysis of ultra-small quantities of Sr and Nd have implications for archaeology, or ecology, where Sr and Nd analysis of artifacts and bones/teeth (archaeology), or analysis of fish otoliths (ecology), are often limited by sample availability. Our method dramatically reduces, by orders of magnitude, the amount of sample required for isotopic analysis, which is an important consideration for analysis of, for example, irreplaceable artifacts, or the analysis of tiny fish otoliths. We expect our analytical developments to be directly transferrable to different fields of study.

This grant played a valuable role carrying out a primary goal: teaching and training the next generation of geochemists. In the PI’s lab group, three PhD students, one Master's student, one postdoctoral researcher, and one undergraduate student were involved in research made possible by this grant. Additionally, this grant provided full or partial support for 11 publications in international peer-reviewed journals, and all publications specifically acknowledge this grant.
